awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Academic Success and Professional Development (ASAP) Project-Based Engineering Excellence Transfer Academy Across Arizona
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project is a collaborative effort between Arizona State University, Central Arizona College, Cochise College, Eastern Arizona College, Estrella Mountain Community College, Glendale Community College, Mesa Community College, Mohave Community College, Phoenix College, and Yavapai College. The program will provide scholarships for talented, low-income students with demonstrated financial need who are pursuing degrees in engineering or computer science. In addition to scholarships, the program will provide academic and other support to increase the persistence of these academically talented, low-income students.  The project design includes an academic success and professional development course along with project-based activities.  Faculty and industrial mentors help students to envision the potential career opportunities and benefits available in engineering and computer science. Nine of the ten collaborating schools are classified as Hispanic Serving Institutions. Scholarships and support for low-income and academically talented students, who may not otherwise be able to obtain engineering or computer science degrees will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic well being of the nation.

The project seeks to address the need to expand the engineering and computer science workforce by increasing the success of Arizona State University students including students that transfer from community colleges. The program combines a network of engineering mentors with a successful student-centered and mentor-driven academic success and professional development course to significantly increase the number of community college students that consider, choose, continue and graduate with a bachelor of science in engineering or computer science.  At the center of the proposed initiative is a commitment to involving students in career-shaping projects that will permit them to discover, nurture, and fully develop their technical interests. Guided by grounded theory and social cognitive career theory, the project will also study the factors most central to maintaining effectiveness while scaling up a successful student-centered and mentor-intensive transfer student support system to encompass a larger group of collaborating institutions. Community colleges will play an increasingly important role in educating the nation's engineers. This statewide project will serve as a collaborative model for four-year and two-year schools across the nation. This research will provide knowledge helpful in establishing a transfer student support program in Arizona and will inform other university and community college networks in other parts of the United States. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the engineering and computer science education community.

por.por_cntn:
MCC participated in this ASAP/S-STEM Grant with an R1 University, three other community colleges from our Maricopa County Community College District, and five remotely situated community colleges within the state of Arizona.  Representatives from all institutions engaged in half-day meetings each semester over the period from 2016 through 2019, with one full-day meeting during the summer of 2019.  While there were significant conversations related to this specific grant project during these meetings, the meetings also provided an opportunity for the partner institutions to discus related topics related to supporting STEM students such as transfer and programming. The outcomes of these meetings underscored that the collaborative nature of this project helped strengthen the communication between as well as the understanding of issues throughout the participating institutions. This aspect of the project was negatively impacted when the R1 institution left the project in late 2019.  

Via scholarship awards, the grant clearly assisted students in underrepresented populations to progress toward a degree in a STEM field, again primarily Engineering and Computer Science (See Figure 1). During the period from Fall 2017 through Spring 2021, Mesa Community College (MCC) awarded 48 ASAP/S-STEM scholarships to 30 students. Of the scholarships awarded, 25 (52%) were awarded to underrepresented minority students, 18 (38%) were awarded to female students, with a total of 32 (67%) of the scholarship recipients coming from underrepresented populations in STEM majors (primarily Engineering and Computer Science).


 

 

Moving to an online student application for the scholarship and directly emailing students in Math, Computer Science, Chemistry, and Physics sections typically taken by Engineering and/or Computer Science majors significantly increased the number of applications received for the award.  One issue with using an online application that an institution might want to consider addressing is to add a question to the application having the student indicate they understand what materials need to be submitted in addition to the application in order to be eligible to receive the award.

 

The COVID-19 pandemic arrived during the Spring 2020 semester, about 18 months prior to the end of this project. The U.S. Department of Education, in its 2021 report ?Education in a Pandemic: The Disparate Impacts of COVID-19 on America's Students,? found the pandemic significantly impacted students and exacerbated barriers to student access and success, particularly among students of color. At MCC, all Spring 2020 classes moved online in response to the pandemic, which was a new modality for many of our STEM courses and students. STEM classes remained remote through the Spring 2021 semester, with the exception of Engineering classes that were allowed to be run in a hybrid fashion split between online and in-person content only during the Spring 2021 semester.  During this period, we saw a significant downturn in the number of students applying for the award and an even larger downturn in the number of completed applications.  This decline in participation was likely the result of pandemic-related impacts on students? lives during this time period.


 

 


Last Modified: 09/21/2022
Modified by: Jim Sizemore
